reasoning: I analyzed 10 examples of activation peaks in relation to the genomic annotations. For each example, I examined the location of activation peaks, noting their proximity to specific genes, strength of activation, and pattern consistency across genomes. I identified recurring methyltransferase genes near activation sites, particularly SAM-dependent methyltransferases, and observed a consistent pattern across diverse bacterial species.
findings: Strong activation peaks were consistently observed in close proximity to methyltransferase genes or methyltransferase-related domains. Specifically, multiple examples showed activation near SAM (S-adenosyl methionine) dependent methyltransferases (section_3, section_8) or other methyltransferase types: UbiG/methylase proteins (section_4, section_9), RquA methyltransferase (section_6), HemK methyltransferase (section_2), and MobA in a molybdopterin pathway (section_5). The activation pattern was remarkably consistent across diverse bacterial phyla, including proteobacteria, firmicutes, and actinobacteria.
conclusion: This feature robustly detects methyltransferase genes across diverse bacterial genomes, with particular sensitivity to SAM-dependent methyltransferases and other methylation-related enzymes.
title: Bacterial Methyltransferase Detection Feature
description: This feature specifically detects methyltransferase genes and related methylation machinery across bacterial genomes. It consistently shows strong spike activation in genes encoding various methyltransferases, including SAM-dependent methyltransferases, UbiG family methylases, MobA, HemK and other methylation-related enzymes. The activation is highly specific to the gene body or immediate vicinity of these enzymes, suggesting it may be detecting conserved sequence motifs or structural elements shared among diverse methyltransferase families. The consistent detection across various bacterial phyla (including proteobacteria, firmicutes, and actinobacteria) indicates this represents a deeply conserved feature of bacterial methylation systems. This feature likely corresponds to important functional domains or catalytic sites within these enzymes that are essential for methylation reactions in bacterial metabolism and gene regulation.
